TF024407-NTF-ESSD SOCIAL WINDOW : INDIA
            TRIBAL RIGHTS IN PROTECTED AREAS,TF034594-INDIA - ECODEVELOPMENT PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for Ecodevelopment Project
            for India were the following: the outcome was satisfactory,
            the sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was substantial, and the Bank and borrower
            performance were both satisfactory. The lessons learned
            indicate that the project helped improve relations between
            forest departments and local people from a high conflict
            situation to one of improved cooperation and collaboration
            through implementation of the ecodevelopment model. The
            creation of microplans and community funds linked village
            development to Protected Area (PA) protection and provided
            villagers with choices about livelihood and development
            options. The long-term sustainability and success of the
            ecodevelopment programs and individual Ecodevelopment
            Committees (EDCs) can be enhanced through linkages to
            political processes and local and national government
            programs. India has a strong civil society movement, both
            pro-conservation and pro-poor, and the project attracted
            much criticism for a) sacrificing biodiversity objectives to
            address poverty issues and b) disadvantaging poor
            communities to support wildlife conservation. The need to
            provide 25 percent co-financing towards ecodevelopment
            activities led to some village families being excluded from
            ecodevelopment benefits.
